rsbNotes.title: Luke 11:14–15
rsbNotes.text: 11:14, 15 Jesus’ enemies did not deny that He expelled demons, but ascribed His power to Beelzebul, the name of a heathen god (2 Kin. 1:2; Matt. 10:25 note).

rsbNotes.title: Luke 11:17–18
rsbNotes.text: 11:17, 18 Unity is strength; Satan is not casting out his own workers.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 11:20
rsbNotes.text: 11:20 the finger of God. As in Ex. 8:19, this figure describes the work of God Himself; Matt. 12:28 reads “the Spirit of God.” Both statements bring out the truth that Jesus did not cast out demons by Beelzebul. The power of God was at work in Him. This points to a further truth: in the coming of Jesus the kingdom of God has come. The miracles He performs are evidence for those who have eyes to see that God is at work.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 11:21–22
rsbNotes.text: 11:21, 22 Satan is like a strong man in complete control of his house, the people under his power. But Jesus is stronger than Satan and overthrows him. This parable teaches that the kingdom of God is not simply a matter of helpful teaching; it comes with power to overcome Satan.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 11:23
rsbNotes.text: 11:23 There can be no neutrality. The message of the kingdom brings the possibility of overcoming evil, and anyone who rejects this message accepts the ways of evil. There is no middle course.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 11:24
rsbNotes.text: 11:24 house from which I came. The demon talks about the place he left as if he still owned it.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 11:25
rsbNotes.text: 11:25 swept and put in order. The man has cleaned up his life, but nothing more. His life is empty, and therefore open to any evil influence.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 11:28
rsbNotes.text: 11:28 rather. Jesus does not deny that Mary was blessed; He is saying that hearing and obeying God’s word is more important.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 11:29
rsbNotes.text: 11:29 a sign. Here Jesus responds to the demand for a “sign from heaven” (v. 16). Such a request could only have been motivated by unbelief, especially in view of the many demonstrations of messianic power already performed by Jesus (7:20–23). For Luke, Jesus’ own presence is a “sign” of God’s redemptive activity (2:34; 11:30).

rsbNotes.title: Luke 11:30
rsbNotes.text: 11:30 Just as Jonah’s three days inside the fish was a sign to the people of Nineveh, so Jesus’ resurrection after three days in the tomb would be a sign to the Jews of His day.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 11:31
rsbNotes.text: 11:31 The queen of the South. That is, the queen of Sheba (in southern Arabia) who made a long and difficult journey to hear Solomon (1 Kin. 10).

rsbNotes.title: Luke 11:32
rsbNotes.text: 11:32 men of Nineveh. The Ninevites who repented when Jonah preached (Jon. 3:6–10). In both cases the argument is from the lesser to the greater. People responded to Solomon and to Jonah; much more should they respond to the Son of God.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 11:34
rsbNotes.text: 11:34 the lamp of your body. When the eye is functioning correctly the body receives the benefit of light (“is full of light”; cf. Ps. 18:28). The people seeking a sign did not need more light, but better receptiveness to the light they already had. What God was doing in Jesus was plain enough.
